summary: This is a 2025 memorandum from the DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) to the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) providing a status update on the BOP's implementation of recommendations from the OIG's 2023 final report on the custody and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It details the BOP's responses to eight recommendations aimed at improving suicide prevention, inmate monitoring, staffing, and security systems.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody and suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center was the subject of the original OIG investigation that prompted the recommendations being tracked in this memorandum.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General issued its final report on the investigation and review of the Federal Bureau of Prisons' custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

events.title: BOP Eliminates Retention Incentives
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons implemented significant reductions and eliminations of staff retention incentives agencywide due to budgetary constraints.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, New York
keyFacts: The memorandum tracks the BOP's progress on eight recommendations from a 2023 OIG report on the failures leading to Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody.
All recommendations except one (Recommendation 7, previously closed) are currently marked as 'Resolved' but not yet closed, pending final policy implementation and OIG review.

Key policy revisions in progress include updates to Program Statements on suicide prevention (5324.08), unit management (5321.09), correctional services (5500.14), and facilities operations (4200.12).
The BOP reported that due to budget constraints, it eliminated agency-wide staff retention incentives in March 2025, which had previously improved staff retention rates.
The OIG is awaiting further action from the BOP, including finalized policies, updates on staffing incentive funding, and reports to Congress and GAO, before considering the recommendations closed.
